Author: jrockway
Content:
Reddit could have done something about this, though. If being downmodded hurt your karma, I bet people would think twice before flaming.

It works here. I avoid flaming and trolling because I like my karma to increase. When I still read reddit, I would often troll, be overly cyncial, or generally be an ass because there was nothing to lose. (Reddit is too mainstream for there to be any intelligence there now. There is the occasional good comment from someone, but the good comments are way too hard to find.)

Author: mlinsey
Content: Hopefully this will be good news for Brazil in the long run - but I worry that becoming a major oil exporter will be much worse for the Brazilian people.  The ideal workforce to make a country rich from technology and innovation is a well-educated, relatively free one that can experiment and be creative.  The ideal workforce to make a country rich from a natural resource is a poorly educated one that will fall in line with the regime that controls the resource. Monopolies and tyrannies are bad for hacking but great for pumping oil.

Author: geebee
Content: It challenges common sense, but I'm surprised it confused so many people.  When I first heard it, I was sceptical enough that I wrote a program to simulate it.  But once it was built, there was essentially no reason to run it.  Once you break the possible outcome into all the cases, it's clear what the success ratio will be just from looking at the algorithm.

Author: carterschonwald
Content:
Actually thats just Bob's copy of Chris' thesis, the book covers that plus a bunch of techniques that other people also cooked up. But the thesis covers enough stuff that it'll give you a good sense of whether or not the work is a worthwhile investment.

Be warned, what you get out of this material in terms of understanding is strictly proportional to your comfort in mathematical reasoning

Author: watmough
Content:
Clojure is a Lisp that compiles to JVM byte-code as you type in to a REPL, or load-file.

Clojure is oriented towards functional style programming and concurrency.

Compiled code uses some reflection under the covers, but most of this can be eliminated by type hinting, which gets you into the ball park with Java.

Author: carterschonwald
Content:
Chris Okasaki's "Purely Functional Data Structures" covers exactly that which is lacking in a standard reference such as CLRS "Introduction to Algorithms". Read / work through both and you're well on your way to being great at algorithmic problem solving

edit: for those who are too lazy to google, here's the book on amazon http://www.amazon.com/Purely-Functional-Structures-Chris-Oka...

Author: plusbryan
Title: Likebetter.com (YC) is looking for a cofounder - get in two floors up
Content:
Likebetter.com started life in the YC Su06 founders program. I'm a single founder, but while likebetter is looking more promising than ever, life dictates that I find someone else to take the reins.

Likebetter.com has been featured on the BBC, the front page of Digg, and in countless blogs. Traffic is decent at 30K uniques, we clearly have our share of addicts, and our widgetbox widget traffic is growing: we have just under 6K active subscriptions.

Most exciting: Two weeks ago, I signed a two year profit-sharing partnership agreement with the largest syndication house in the US, that seeks to promote the likebetter widget to the largest newspapers and magazines across the nation for use on their sites (pet wars, best photo contests, etc). The site will need some work to ready it for this (RoR+javascript), but the profit potential is high.

After working on likebetter for more than two years, I feel that it's just at the cusp of finding its stride. I'm seeking the right person or pair that can help guide it home. To be clear: I am not looking for a traditional 'cofounder'. For all intents and purposes, I'd play the role of an adviser and to some extent help cover base costs; but my other commitments won't allow me to play an active role in the development of the business nor the site.

If for whatever reason you applied and were not admitted to YC, or are considering applying but don't have the right idea - consider this: You'd be getting in 2 floors above the ground floor, and, to the right person, I'm prepared to hand over the same equity as if you joined me on the ground floor two years ago.

If this sounds like the opportunity for you, email me plusbryan AT gmail.com

I'm located in SF and would like to meet with you in person, though the final location of the business is of no consequence.

pairwise.com\nlikebetter.com

Author: donw
Content:
I've been thinking quite a bit recently on the subject of online forums; namely, why do they seem to inevitably deteriorate into a desperate, trolling flame-fest? More to the point, how can this be prevented? What can be learned from other forms of group communication, such as scientific journals?

The author makes a point that I hadn't really thought much about; namely, that observing the mayhem is itself entertaining to a large number of people, which in turn drives site owners to, at the very least unconsciously, permit nearly uncontrolled ass-hattery, in exchange for eyeballs and advertising revenue.

JoS seems to have maintained a decent signal-to-noise ratio; let's hope that Hacker News manages to do so as well.
